Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: BIOSIGNAL MUSIC DISCOVERY HEADPHONES
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project results from its potential to significantly change the way humans interact with intelligent systems. The ability to determine human emotion, level of consciousness, activity levels and facial gesture controls using affordable, wearable technology has the potential to disrupt the technology industry. The proposed technology will empower developers to create software applications that learn about individual user preferences based on the user's biosignals and serve highly relevant content to those users. The potential impact of the technology extends well beyond the proposed music discovery application to include news, videos, books, pictures, targeted advertising, custom hands-free facial gesture controls, activity/fitness tracking, etc. The technology also enables remote (live and pre-recorded) suggestive psychotherapy treatment applications by allowing audio streams to be correlated with human mental/biological states. The number of life-changing applications that can be developed using the proposed technology is limited only by the imaginations of third party developers. The initial implementation of the proposed technology will be in consumer headphones.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project proposes to develop a technology that will power the first-ever Biosignal Headphones. The proposed technology monitors a user's biosignals - such as brainwaves (EEG), muscle signals (EMG) and heart rate (ECG) - and makes determinations regarding user emotions, level of consciousness, facial gestures and activity levels. The interpreted biosignal information can be sent to personal smartphones, computers, media players, etc. where it can be used in applications developed by third party developers. For example, while a user is listening to music powered by a music discovery application, biosignal-equipped headphones will report to the application whether or not the user is enjoying a song, which will feed the discovery process that recommends artists/songs the user is likely to enjoy. In another example, while a user is jogging, the headphones can provide activity tracking metrics and play music that corresponds to endurance levels. The biosignal headphones could also enable applications for at-home remote suggestive psychotherapy to treat conditions such as Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The initial research objective was to incorporate biosensors into smart headphones that would monitor user bio-signals, determine emotion and correlate that with music being played. The idea was to have headphones that could determine which songs a user preferred and play/discover more songs with similar attributes. Imagine your listening to Pandora and the headphones would auto thumbs up or thumbs down a song.  After constructing a testbed using off the shelf   components such as a wireless Bluetooth transceiver, accelerometer, dry-contact EEG sensors, thermometer, heart rate sensors and headphones we were able to quickly make several determinations. Off the shelf, consumer grade EEG sensors have poor fidelity. The amplitude values of alpha, beta, theta and delta waves are primarily driven by facial muscle tension, not EEG as advertised. When you see a demo of a user changing tv channels, flying drones or playing video games with single channel, dry-contact forehead sensor it is likely the muscular tension (EMG) in the forehead contracting and relaxing as a user is told to relax and focus as opposed to EEG signals. We mounted the dry-contact sensors onto a user’s temple and were able to measure eye movement (EOG) signals with high fidelity.

We decided to transform our Biosignal Headphone testbed into a Biosignal Sleep Mask testbed. The Sleep Mask transmitted eye movement data, motion data, heart rate data and blood oxygen level data to a smartphone. The data could be visualized in real-time on the smartphone or through our backend portal hosted on Amazon Web Services (AWS). With the sleep mask we were able to accurately detect periods of REM sleep as well as other vital sign data that indicated how a user sleeps.  After consulting with renowned sleep experts, we were guided to incorporate a respiration sensor. Most sleep disorders are a result of sleep apnea and there are currently no off the shelf wearable sensors that measure how well you breath. We quickly prototyped a chest strap with a motion sensor that was able to accurately measure breathing patterns. We built an end-to-end functional prototype that would allow sleep physicians to view all this data in real-time and/or save in our database for later use. It turns out we were on to something important since approximately 18 million people in the United States suffer from sleep apnea and most go untreated.  Reasons for not getting treated are mainly attributed to the onerous process of visiting a sleep center and getting diagnosed. There doesn’t exist any easy to use device for measuring/monitoring breathing that you could buy at a local drugstore like you would buy a scale to measure weight or blood pressure cuff to measure blood pressure.  An area that needs further research is form-factor. While our prototype was smaller, less bulky and more comfortable than anything on the market, users still seemed to unconsciously remove the wearable sensor at some point while they were sleeping.

During this research, the principal investigator (PI) welcomed his first child into the world. One night the PI and his wife found themselves starring at the video baby monitor unsure if the baby was breathing so they ran into the room. Luckily they baby was just fine, it was just hard to see the breathing motion on the video feed. This scenario happened several times and the PI thought, there has to be a better way! He worked with his team to repackage the aforementioned sleep/respiration monitoring technology into a small wearable form factor that clipped onto the babies diaper. The PI was able to monitor the baby’s vital signs and motion on his smartphone throughout the night giving him a peace of mind.
